verb.description: Decorate (something) in an artistic or attractive way.
examples: they had dressed the doorframes with sprays of bittersweet

verb.description: Treat or prepare (something) in a certain way.
Draw up (troops) in the proper alignment.
Prepare (an artificial fly) for use in fishing.
examples: after you dress a dry fly, be sure to remove any oil before you make your next cast

noun.description: A one-piece garment for a woman or girl that covers the body and extends down over the legs.
Clothing of a specified kind for men or women.
examples: the underlying theme is recognizable even when it appears in feminist dress

phrases: there I was, all dressed up with nowhere to go, in the ritziest part of town
the last-minute withdrawal of two star singers left the orchestra all dressed up with nowhere to go
Then Sally emerged, dressed to kill - in skin tight black leggings, black thigh length PVC stiletto boots, and an outrageous Puffa jacket.
Yet made up and dressed to kill, some of them could have passed for 28.
They have three things in common: they have been friends for years, they are all single, and they are dressed to kill.
Sue dressed down in old jeans and a white blouse
Charcoal, black - even neon green, these jackets are perfect for dressing up or dressing down.
The same juvenile impulse that once inspired liberals to dress down as slobs now inspires them to assume the role of high school snobs.
While dressing down is all good and fun, award shows are about the red carpet.
The annual Halloween Fancy Dress Night is a fundraiser for the Hospice, so guests should use their imaginations while dressing up or dressing down as the case may be.
origin: Middle English (in the sense put straight): from Old French dresser arrange, prepare, based on Latin directus direct, straight.
